Walter J. Ong (1912-2003) was an American Jesuit priest, professor of English, and cultural historian. He was best known for his work on the impact of oral and written cultures on the development of human consciousness and culture. Ong's research focused on the transition from orality to literacy and its effects on language, thought, and culture.

One of his most important works is "Orality and Literacy: The Technologizing of the Word", where he discusses Plato's critique of writing and provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of writing on human communication and culture. Ong argues that the shift from an oral culture to a literate culture changed the way people think, learn, and remember information, and that it has had a profound impact on human history.

Ong was widely recognized as one of the leading experts on the history of human communication and was awarded numerous honors and awards for his contributions to the field. He remains one of the most widely read and influential scholars in the field of cultural history and the study of orality and literacy.
